summary: Create Domain Environment Setup Unified Pipeline
description:

summary: EVA: create stable IAC resources in dev and preprod
description:
As BIP Eng, we would like to migrate environments into different clusters as needed so that tenants can have better isolation.

_Acceptance Criteria:_
 # Assess current environment cluster distribution
 # Plan migration strategy for tenant isolation
 # Create automated migration scripts and procedures
 # Test migration process in lower environments
 # Execute production migrations with minimal downtime
 # Validate tenant isolation and performance post-migration

_Associated GitHub Repositories:_
* bip-infrastructure: Cluster provisioning and migration automation
* bip-tooling-crossplane-apis: Multi-cluster API management
* bip-tenant-intake: Tenant environment configuration

_Notes_

summary: TERA: endpoint cleanup in CI/CD
description: Ticket Name: TERA endpoint cleanup Value Statement: "As a TERA or BIP-AI engineer when I run the ci/cd process to create a new TERA NRT endpoint the previously created endpoint should be removed to prevent additional charges. This ticket is to delete any existing endpoints that are no longer being used by the TERA team and investigate if an automatic endpoint cleanup step can be added to the current ci/cid pipeline as well as updating the API Gateway configuration" AC - Screenshot showing endpoints for TERA cleaned up in dev, stage + preprod - Write up of investigation into testing automated cleanup process - PR including automated removal of endpoints if possible

summary: EVA: code formatting and mock tests / coverage in github actions
description: Title: Add code formatting, test coverage and validation to github CI checks for EVA's repository Value Statement: As a BIP AI mlops developer who supports EVA, I need a CI pipeline that checks code formatting, runs test validation and checks test coverage on EVA's PRs so that I can ensure new code meets testing and formatting requirements. AC: Checks are added for black formatting, test coverage, and runs tests to validate passing tests to be run on new PR.

summary: Create IaC for MLOps API in MGMT cluster
description:
Title: Deploy mlops-manager to mgmt cluster for MLOps service access

Value Statement: As an infrastructure engineer who deploys platform services, I need the ability to deploy the MLOPS manager to the mgmt cluster so that I can make MLOps services available through the AI platform.

Acceptance Criteria: When a user accesses the MLOPS manager endpoints, the user has the ability to interact with both the API and frontend services. MLOPS manager API is deployed and running on the mgmt cluster Pods are healthy and stable

summary: Develop BIP-AI AWS provider config and IRSA to maintain composition functionality after platform deprecation
description:
Develop BIP-AI AWS provider config and IRSA to maintain composition functionality after platform deprecation

Story: As an infrastructure engineer, I want to create and deploy our own AWS provider config and IRSA role so that our Crossplane compositions continue to function independently after the platform deprecates the shared provider config.

Assumptions: - Platform deprecation timeline allows for SBX testing and validation before cutover - Current compositions use a consistent provider config reference pattern that can be systematically replaced - Required AWS permissions for BIP-AI use-cases can be identified from existing composition resource types

Acceptance Criteria: - Given BIP-AI infrastructure requirements when I define the IRSA role then it includes only the minimum AWS permissions needed for our composition resource types - Given the new provider config when I deploy it with our compositions then it successfully authenticates using the BIP-AI IRSA role - Given all existing BIP-AI compositions when I update their provider config references then each composition references the new BIP-AI provider config - Given the updated compositions when I deploy them in SBX then all resources provision successfully using the new provider config and IRSA - Given a composition deployment when it uses the new provider config then no references to the deprecated platform provider config remain - Given the new IRSA role when I review its permissions then it follows least-privilege principles for the APIs accessed by our compositions

Definition of Done: - All acceptance criteria met - Tests added/updated (integration testing in SBX) - Documentation updated (README / runbook covering provider config deployment and IRSA role configuration) - Security and access controls reviewed - Dependencies updated and migrations applied

summary: Implement crossplane composition for kubernetes app deployments
description:
Title: Implement crossplane composition for kubernetes app deployments

Value Statement: As an infrastructure engineer who automates application deployments, I need the ability to use a crossplane composition for kubernetes apps so that I can deploy applications consistently and efficiently.

Acceptance Criteria: When a user creates a claim using the k8s-app composition, the user has the ability to deploy a kubernetes application following the approved design. The k8s-app crossplane composition is implemented according to the design document from [BIP-29494|https://jira.devops.va.gov/browse/BIP-29494] Composition includes all resources defined in the design document Documentation is updated with usage examples and patterns Automated or manual tests validate the composition deploys applications successfully

Dependencies: This story is dependent on the completion of: [BIP-29494|https://jira.devops.va.gov/browse/BIP-29494](Design document)

description:
title: Gen-Ann: Support UserMetrics job SQL development in ProdTest

VS: As a platform SE for the Gen-Ann tenant, I want to provide configuration, deployment, and observability support so the tenant can iterate on their User Metrics module logic (SQL, etc.) in Prodtest via standalone Sagemaker job runs, and then integrate the finalized module into the Sagemaker pipeline for deployment, ensuring a smooth path from module testing to pipeline execution.

 - Conduct working sessions with the tenant to validate real DB connectivity in Prodtest and successful data retrieval.
 - Confirm with the tenant complete platform enablement and a repeatable method for them to iterate on their business logic independently without platform support

summary: EVA: make Jenkins deployment configurable by part and stability set (dev/preprod)
description:
title: EVA: make Jenkins deployment configurable by part and stability set (dev/preprod) 

Value Statement: As a platform SE supporting the EVA tenant, I want Jenkins to support targeted deployments by system part (build, agents, lambdas, kbs) and by stability set (stable or test) for dev and preprod, while defaulting to full-system deploys. This enables faster, safer, and more focused releases without disrupting unrelated components, and preserves a simple default behavior for comprehensive deployments.

AC:
- Jenkins deployment job accepts a parameter to select one or more parts from [build, agents, lambdas, kbs]. Only the specified parts are deployed. Default = all.
- Jenkins deployment job accepts parameters: environment (dev/preprod) and stability (test/stable). Default = stable.
- A mapping exists to distinguish test vs stable resources and resources between part sets.

summary: Update Tenant API for Crossplane Auto Tagger
description:
Title: Update Tenant API for crossplane autotagger to retrieve tags by ApplicationId

Acceptance Criteria: A new API route is created /tenans/\{ApplicationId}/tags which returns the tags object

summary: Refactor Usage protection to parent resources and add deletion protection flag to enhance protection and intended deletion
description:
Refactor Usage protection to parent resources and add deletion protection flag to enhance protection and intended deletion

Story: As an infrastructure engineer, I want Usage constraints applied only to Claims and Composites so that resources are protected from unintended deletion while remaining simple to remove when intentional.

Assumptions: - Some compositions already implement a deletion protection flag pattern that can be standardized - ArgoCD is the primary tool causing unintended deletion flags on child resources - Claims are the preferred parent resource when available, otherwise Composites are used

Acceptance Criteria: - Given a composition that uses Claims when I apply Usage constraints then they protect only the Claim resource and storage resources - Given a composition without Claims when I apply Usage constraints then they protect only the Composite resource and storage resources - Given all BIP-AI compositions when I review Usage definitions then child resources no longer have Usage constraints except for storage - Given a composition with the deletion protection flag when I set it to disable protection then all Usage constraints are bypassed to allow deletion - Given a composition with the deletion protection flag when I leave it unset then it defaults to enabled and Usage constraints remain active - Given all BIP-AI compositions when I review the XRD then each includes a standardized deletion protection parameter matching the existing pattern - Given the refactored compositions deployed in SBX when I test deletion scenarios then protected resources block deletion and unprotected resources delete successfully

Definition of Done: - All acceptance criteria met - Tests added/updated (integration testing in SBX) - Documentation updated (README / runbook covering Usage patterns and deletion protection flag) - Dependencies updated and migrations applied

summary: Implement API tag updater
description:
*Value Statement:* As a member of the BIP-AI infrastructure team, I need to implement the API drive Auto-tag system updater.

*A/C:*  Implement the API driven Auto-Tag system updater

summary: Fix Crossplane manager EntraID group permissions to enable tenant resource visibility
description:
Fix Crossplane manager EntraID group permissions to enable tenant resource visibility

Story: As a tenant user, I want to view my Sagemaker Domains and other resources on the BIP-AI Gateway so that I can manage and access the resources provisioned for my team.

Assumptions: - The Python-based implementation demonstrates the correct EntraID group-to-tenant mapping pattern - The issue affects all resource types retrieved through the same route, not just Domains - DEV environment has sufficient diversity of user roles and EntraID groups to validate the fix.

Acceptance Criteria: - Given a tenant user with an EntraID group when I navigate to the Domains page then I see all Sagemaker Domains associated with my tenant - Given a tenant user when the manager processes my request then it correctly maps my EntraID group to the corresponding tenant name - Given the fixed Go-based manager when it retrieves tenant resources then it applies the same authorization logic as the working Python implementation - Given a tenant user with access to multiple resource types when I view each resource page then all resources associated with my tenant are visible - Given the updated manager deployed in SBX when I test resource retrieval then tenant resources display correctly for test users - Given the updated manager deployed in DEV when developers with diverse roles test then each user sees only their tenant resources.

Definition of Done: - All acceptance criteria met - Tests added/updated (unit/integration as applicable) - Documentation updated (README / runbook as applicable) - Security and access controls reviewed - Dependencies updated and migrations applied

summary: Add Eventbridge enablement in Bedrock module for BDA invocation
description:
Title: Enable EventBridge for BDA Project Invocation in mlkit Bedrock module

Value Statement: As a BIP-AI MLOps Engineer, I need the mlkit Bedrock module to emit BDA Project Invocation events to EventBridge so downstream systems can react to invocations with standardized, observable, and decoupled event-driven workflows.

Acceptance Criteria: - Update the mlkit Bedrock module to publish BDA Project Invocation events to EventBridge - update unit tests accordingly

summary: DynamoDb example tutorial notebook
description:
Title:
DynamoDB example tutorial notebook

Value Statement:
As a BIP-AI tenant who wants to persist and query application data efficiently, I need to learn how to use Amazon DynamoDB within BIP-AI to design tables, perform CRUD operations, and implement scalable, low-latency data access patterns for AI-driven workflows.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Jupyter notebook explaining core DynamoDB concepts relevant to BIP-AI (table design, keys, capacity, indexes).
- Example setup: create a table and perform basic CRUD using the AWS SDK from BIP-AI.
- Query and scan demonstrations, including key conditions and pagination.
- Use of at least one secondary index aligned to an example access pattern.
- Basic observability and security: CloudWatch metrics/logs, and least-privilege IAM guidance.

summary: Research and explore enabling comprehend usage tagging
description: AC: Create tagged comprehend project and validate in cost explorer that costs are being tracked. Work with infra to create tagging enforced policy for comprehend use.

summary: Lambda functional code in mlkit
description:
Title: Add Reusable Functional Code from Lambda Tutorial Notebook into mlkit Repository

Value Statement: As a BIP MLOps engineer, I want to extract and centralize reusable Lambda-related utility code from the Lambda Usage Tutorial Notebook into the shared mlkit repository, so that commonly used functions and classes can be easily imported and maintained across multiple projects without code duplication.

Description: The Lambda Usage Tutorial Notebook currently includes functional code (e.g., Lambda creation, configuration, and invocation helpers) that can be reused in other notebooks and pipelines. This task involves identifying such reusable code segments, refactoring them into standalone Python modules within the mlkit repository, and updating the tutorial notebook to import those utilities instead of redefining them locally. This will promote better maintainability, consistency, and reusability across all projects using Lambda or SageMaker automation.

Acceptance Criteria: Code Identification - Review the Lambda Usage Tutorial Notebook and identify all code components suitable for reuse (e.g., Lambda creation, invocation, S3 interaction, logging utilities). Refactoring and Module Creation - Move reusable logic into the mlkit repository under an appropriate directory - Ensure code is modular, well-documented, and follows internal coding standards. - Functions and classes should include docstrings and type hints. Testing - Add or update unit tests in the mlkit repo to verify the moved code functions as expected. Notebook Update - Update the Lambda Usage Tutorial Notebook to import the refactored functions/classes from mlkit. Documentation - Add or update README/documentation within mlkit describing the new utilities and their usage.

summary: Review Bedrock manager in mlkit to adjust tenant needs
description:
Value Statement As a MLOps engineer, I want to review the bedrock code in mlkit bedrock manager to decide and edit which functionality to include so that tenants are able to effectively use the tools.

AC: - - Current Bedrock Agent Tutorial Notebook is outdated, update the notebook such that it can run end-to-end without problems. - Ensure that the agent & lambda creation are both done via IaC - Showcase usage of Bedrock Lambda invocation via Action Groups and the alias name creation.

summary: Determine bedrock inference threshold  based on current tenant usage
description:
Title: Define Grafana alert thresholds for Bedrock inference requests based on service quotas and tenant usage.
Value Statement: As a BIP-AI MLOps Engineer, I need data-driven alert thresholds for Bedrock inference requests that account for AWS service quota limits and per-tenant usage patterns so alerts are actionable, minimize noise, and prevent quota-related outages. 
Acceptance Criteria: - Gather and document relevant Bedrock service quotas and analyze historical tenant usage to establish a methodology for threshold calculation (including headroom, trends/seasonality, and safety margins). - Configure tenant grafana alerts for invocation requests using the derived thresholds.

summary: Integrate Image Builder Pipeline with Lambda Deployment Pipeline in Harness
description:
Title: Integrate Image Builder Pipeline with Lambda Deployment Pipeline in Harness

 
Value Statement: As a DevOps engineer, I want to be able to trigger the Image Builder pipeline from within the Lambda Deployment pipeline in Harness, so that I can automatically build the deployment image, consume its outputs, and use them in the subsequent steps of the Lambda deployment process.
 
Acceptance Criteria: Triggering Image Builder from Lambda Pipeline Given I am configuring the Lambda Deployment pipeline in Harness When I add a Run step (or equivalent) that invokes the Image Builder pipeline Then the Lambda Deployment pipeline should be able to: Trigger the Image Builder pipeline via a webhook or pipeline trigger. Pass any required parameters (e.g., commit SHA, branch name, environment, build version). Webhook / Trigger Configuration Given the Image Builder pipeline is configured in Harness When I create a webhook-trigger configuration for it Then: The trigger URL should be accessible from the Lambda Deployment pipeline run step. The trigger should start a new execution of the Image Builder pipeline. Relevant metadata (e.g., pipeline execution ID, build number) is logged and visible in execution details. Synchronous Execution & Status Handling Given the Lambda Deployment pipeline has triggered the Image Builder pipeline When the Image Builder pipeline completes Then: The Lambda Deployment pipeline should wait for the Image Builder pipeline to finish (success or failure). If the Image Builder pipeline fails, the Lambda Deployment pipeline should: Mark the step as failed. Stop further deployment steps (unless explicitly configured otherwise). If the Image Builder pipeline succeeds, the Lambda pipeline should continue to the next steps. Access to Image Builder Outputs Given the Image Builder pipeline produces outputs (e.g., image URI, tag, digest, artifact metadata, version number) When the Lambda Deployment pipeline resumes after the Image Builder pipeline completes Then: These outputs should be available as variables/expressions within the Lambda Deployment pipeline. I should be able to reference these outputs in subsequent steps (e.g., Lambda update function step, environment variables, config files). End-to-End Deployment Using Image Outputs Given a successful run of the Image Builder pipeline within the Lambda Deployment pipeline When the Lambda Deployment pipeline proceeds to its deployment steps Then: The Lambda function(s) should be updated using the newly built image or artifact reference from the Image Builder pipeline. The deployment logs should clearly show which image/tag or artifact version was deployed.

summary: Record end‑to‑end Harness demo: image build through Lambda deployment
description:
Title: Record end‑to‑end Harness demo: image build through Lambda deployment
Value Statement: As a DevOps engineer / enablement lead, I want to record an end-to-end Harness demo that shows the image builder pipeline executing into a Lambda deployment pipeline, so that stakeholders can clearly see the full automated flow from image build to Lambda function deployment and use the recording for training, onboarding, and enablement.
Acceptance Criteria: Scenario & Flow Definition Given I am preparing the demo When I define the scenario Then: The flow must cover: code change → image build pipeline execution → output artifact/image → Lambda deployment pipeline execution using that artifact. The specific pipelines, services, and environments used in the demo are documented (names, purpose, and relationships).

summary: Create a reusable Playwright step template
description:
Value Statement: As a DevOps engineer, I want to create a reusable step template for Playwright tests in Harness, so that I can standardize Playwright execution (using a pre-built image and configuration) and easily reuse this step across pipelines and accelerators.
 
Acceptance Criteria: Playwright Step Template Definition Given I am in the Harness template library When I create a new step template for Playwright Then: The step template is of the correct type (e.g., container/script step appropriate for running Playwright). The template can be versioned and stored in the shared template library. Pre-Built Image with Playwright Given there is a container image with Playwright pre-installed When I configure the step template Then: The template references this image in its configuration. The image includes all necessary Playwright dependencies (Node.js, browsers, drivers, fonts, etc.). The image location (registry URL/tag) can be configured or overridden via inputs if required. Configurable Playwright Command & Arguments

PI demo prep
1.6 - On Call Infra Service Desk
description:
Value Statement: As a BIP AI engineer I need to be On Call so that any service desk tickets that are submitted are addressed in a timely manner.
AC: # Be available and monitor the Service Desk ticket board
 # Address any tickets that come in and begin support
 # Provide continual updates to tickets
 # Reassign to developers as needed

summary: API Gateway Update Script for Lambda and SM endpoint
description:
Title: Script to Update API Gateway for Existing Lambda and SageMaker Endpoints Value Statement: As a tenant platform engineer who manages deployment configurations, I need the ability to update existing API Gateway routes for Lambda functions and SageMaker endpoints so that the APIs are properly routed and accessible after deployment changes.

Acceptance Criteria: - The API Gateway reflects the correct integration targets and routes.

summary: Configure Slack alerts for unified Jenkins deployment pipeline
description:
Title: Configure Slack alerts for unified Jenkins deployment pipeline

Value Statement: As a MLOps engineer who created the unified endpoint deployment pipeline, I need the ability to configure slack alerts so there is a centralized place for notifications

Acceptance Criteria: When a solutions engineer triggers the unified deployment pipeline, they have the ability to view alerts (failures, successes, etc.) in slack

summary: Configure KMS and ECR Policies to Enable Cosign Image Signing with BIP Key
description:
As a DevOps engineer,
I want to configure KMS and ECR policies to allow Cosign to use the BIP signing key stored in KMS for ECR image signing
So that container images pushed to ECR can be securely signed and verified using the centralized BIP key with proper access controls in place.
 
Acceptance Criteria
Ensuring the BIP signing key is created or imported into AWS KMS in the appropriate account(s) and region(s).
Defining and applying appropriate KMS key policies and IAM policies so that:
The CI/CD pipeline / image builder role can use the BIP key for signing (e.g., kms:Sign, kms:GetPublicKey as relevant).
Only approved principals can administer or use the key (principle of least privilege).
Validating that Cosign can retrieve and use the BIP key from KMS during the ECR image signing process.
Ensuring ECR is configured such that signed images and their signatures can be stored, discovered, and verified (e.g., Cosign-compatible OCI artifacts in ECR).

summary: Update Testing and Deployment Strategy Document
description:
Value Statement: As a DevOps engineer / platform engineer I want the testing and deployment strategy documentation to clearly describe how AWS Lambda services are deployed to the Dev environment using Harness deployment workflows So that developers and release engineers can consistently and safely deploy Lambda changes to Dev, following a standard, well-documented process
 
Acceptance Criteria: Update the Testing and Deployment Strategy document with the relevant updates from harness.

summary: Create Custom Fortify Docker Image with Pre-installed Language Dependencies
description:
Value Statement
Building a custom Fortify image with pre-installed language dependencies will eliminate redundant package installations during each scan. Currently, the Fortify scan process spends significant time installing packages for Python, Java, Node.js, and Go on every pipeline run. By creating a reusable image with these dependencies pre-installed and storing it in Nexus or ECR, we can reduce repeated installation overhead and prepare for faster pipeline execution times.Acceptance Criteria *  Custom Docker image built with pre-installed Fortify dependencies for commonly used languages (Python, Java, Node.js, Go)
 *  Image successfully stored in approved registry (Nexus or ECR) and accessible by Harness pipelines
 *  Documentation created for image contents, build process, and maintenance procedures
 *  Image validated to include all necessary dependencies for standard Fortify scans
